review.title: A Tribe Competition-Based Genetic Algorithm for Feature Selection in Pattern Classification
review.abstract: Feature selection has always been a critical step in pattern recognition, in which evolutionary algorithms, such as the genetic algorithm (GA), are most commonly used. However, the individual encoding scheme used in various GAs would either pose a bias on the solution or require a pre-specified number of features, and hence may lead to less accurate results. In this paper, a tribe competition-based genetic algorithm (TCbGA) is proposed for feature selection in pattern classification. The population of individuals is divided into multiple tribes, and the initialization and evolutionary operations are modified to ensure that the number of selected features in each tribe follows a Gaussian distribution. Thus each tribe focuses on exploring a specific part of the solution space. Meanwhile, tribe competition is introduced to the evolution process, which allows the winning tribes, which produce better individuals, to enlarge their sizes, i.e. having more individuals to search their parts of the solution space. This algorithm, therefore, avoids the bias on solutions and requirement of a pre-specified number of features. We have evaluated our algorithm against several state-of-the-art feature selection approaches on 20 benchmark datasets. Our results suggest that the proposed TCbGA algorithm can identify the optimal feature subset more effectively and produce more accurate pattern classification.

sections.heading: 2. Algorithm
sections.text: As a heuristically oriented parallel and stochastic search approach, TCbGA seeks a globally optimal subset of candidate characteristics through the development of a population of individuals. Each individual encodes a trait selection scheme using binary coding and has a fitness defined as classification accuracy, which is achieved by applying these selected characteristics to the linear SVM [32] in 10-fold cross-validation. Since it is difficult to estimate how many characteristics are selected in the global optimal solution, and without this value traditional binary coded GA tends to select approximately 2-fold characteristics, we divide the solution space into overlapping subspaces and accordingly divide the population equally into strains exploring a subspace. These strains develop in two-tiered sequence. In the intra-tribal evolutionary step, each strain develops independently and the highest fitness therein improves as the new generations of the tribe mutually modify the pre-selective, mutually selective, mutually mutually selective, and mutually adaptive fitness processes.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we propose the TCbGA algorithm for trait selection in pattern classification, which divides the population into several tribes, each containing a cohort of individuals. We code each individual as a binary string to represent a possible trait selection scheme, and modify the initialization and evolutionary operations to ensure that the number of selected traits in each tribe follows a Gaussian distribution. In addition to developing each tribe, we are introducing a tribal competition to allow elite individuals an increased search power. Our results suggest that the proposed algorithm exceeds several state-of-the-art selection approaches to 20 benchmark datasets. Our future work will focus on integrating classifier selection into the optimization process, reducing complexity, and expanding this algorithm to solve trait selection problems with a large set of features.
